channel.title: Afk kicker
channel.description: using the "[Hyperion]Project Annihilation Official release" base, and i was wondering how i turn off the afk kick? it kicks me every minute, and it's starting to piss me off, lol.

item.title: Afk kicker
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Dan0194, post:19, topic:548929”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=667836.msg4466368#msg4466368 date=1420357622]

so you’re saying i should change it?

Correct.
[/quote]

Sk8r’s right if your going to change the time the packet is sent you should do it via the client not the server because there is no reason for the client to be sending the server anything if your not going to use it.[/quote]

I agree. But as I said, if he doesn’t have a “good” way of handling code updates made to the client, then (if he has a sizable player base) players will likely get the impression that the client/server is unstable and turn away from it. If he doesn’t care, then by all means change the value in the client. In other games I have played, and other applications I’ve developed, disconnects like this are better handled on the server side, because then only one aspect is changed.

The server can control the idle timeout from 1 minute to 10 minutes, to 30 seconds, and no user has to do anything on their side; which is really what making an RSPS is usually about. It’s not the best exercise in learning how to program (and certainly not how to program well in most cases), or learn about how networking actually works, and it’s usually not for your own personal use (few people actually host a server whose maximum expected population is 3). It’s about getting as many players as possible in your game, which translates to getting as many dollars flowing into your bank account as possible (via “donations” or “premium features” and ad revenue).

Read full topic

item.title: Afk kicker
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:18, topic:548929”][quote author=petterrs96 link=topic=667836.msg4466367#msg4466367 date=1420357565]
so you’re saying i should change it?
[/quote]
Correct.[/quote]

Sk8r’s right if your going to change the time the packet is sent you should do it via the client not the server because there is no reason for the client to be sending the server anything if your not going to use it.

Read full topic

item.title: Afk kicker
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Zymus, post:15, topic:548929”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=667836.msg4466338#msg4466338 date=1420348781]
You seriously shouldn’t even be handling any of this server sided. It’s a packet… I even liked you to the RSWiki giving information on the packet… C’mon…
[/quote]

Are you saying that server’s shouldn’t have packets?

I think it’s the best solution that achieves what you want, and doesn’t require players to re-download the client. If you want them to download a new version of the client, you should probably send the actual timeout delay on logon (the 4500 to 45000).[/quote]
No, I’m saying you shouldn’t be “cheap hacking” it the way you are.
I did this (and released a shitty tut on it), and got a lot of flack about it, that’s actually how I ended up finding the info on how the packet works and to change the 4500 to 45000…

If a new client is the issue, then OP/etc should add a proper update handler in the client…

Read full topic

item.title: Afk kicker
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

sk8rdude461:

You seriously shouldn’t even be handling any of this server sided. It’s a packet… I even liked you to the RSWiki giving information on the packet… C’mon…

Are you saying that server’s shouldn’t have packets?

I think it’s the best solution that achieves what you want, and doesn’t require players to re-download the client. If you want them to download a new version of the client, you should probably send the actual timeout delay on logon (the 4500 to 45000).

Read full topic

item.title: Afk kicker
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Beemobmo71, post:12, topic:548929”][quote author=Zymus link=topic=667836.msg4466290#msg4466290 date=1420330107]

Zymus it’s called when the server receives the packet from the client.
If I remember correctly, the packet is sent 1 time when the player is idle for 1 minute, and then sent every 10 seconds afterwards.

However, you can modify the client to just send it after 10 minutes.

You look in the client for something like:

super.idleTime++; if(super.idleTime > 4500) {
And change the 4500 to 45000.

Is it a packet sent from the client to the server? I thought it was one sent to the client?

Anyways, to get this effect without modifying the client, and requiring all of your players to download it again (if you don’t have an auto updater), you can do it on the server side.

In your Player class, you can add a field

public class Player {

    // ...

    public long getTimeLastPacketReceived() {
        return timeLastPacketReceived;
    }

    public long updateTimeLastPacketReceived() {
        timeLastPacketReceived = System.currentTimeMillis();
    }

    private long timeLastIdlePacketReceived;

And then in your packet handler

public class IdlePacketHandler {

    public IdlePacketHandler(final long timeout) {
        this.timeout = timeout;
    }

    public void handle(final Player player, final Packet packet) {
        final long timeDifference = System.currentTimeMillis() - player.getTimeLastIdlePacketReceived();
        if (timeDifference >= timeout) {
            player.getActionSender().sendLogout(false);
            player.updateTimeLastIdlePacketReceived();
        }
    }

    private long timeout;
}

Then you can specify the timeout as

new IdlePacketHandler(10000); // number of milliseconds, this is 10 seconds

[/quote]

Would that happen to be for Delta? And Would you put the “new IdlePacketHandler(10000);” under case 202?[/quote]

I have no idea.

Read full topic

item.title: Afk kicker
item.dc:creator: @Beemobmo71 Beemobmo71
item.description:
@Beemobmo71 wrote:

[quote=“Zymus, post:8, topic:548929”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=667836.msg4466269#msg4466269 date=1420323583]
Zymus it’s called when the server receives the packet from the client.
If I remember correctly, the packet is sent 1 time when the player is idle for 1 minute, and then sent every 10 seconds afterwards.

However, you can modify the client to just send it after 10 minutes.

You look in the client for something like:

super.idleTime++; if(super.idleTime > 4500) {
And change the 4500 to 45000.
[/quote]

Is it a packet sent from the client to the server? I thought it was one sent to the client?

Anyways, to get this effect without modifying the client, and requiring all of your players to download it again (if you don’t have an auto updater), you can do it on the server side.

In your Player class, you can add a field

public class Player {

    // ...

    public long getTimeLastPacketReceived() {
        return timeLastPacketReceived;
    }

    public long updateTimeLastPacketReceived() {
        timeLastPacketReceived = System.currentTimeMillis();
    }

    private long timeLastIdlePacketReceived;

And then in your packet handler

public class IdlePacketHandler {

    public IdlePacketHandler(final long timeout) {
        this.timeout = timeout;
    }

    public void handle(final Player player, final Packet packet) {
        final long timeDifference = System.currentTimeMillis() - player.getTimeLastIdlePacketReceived();
        if (timeDifference >= timeout) {
            player.getActionSender().sendLogout(false);
            player.updateTimeLastIdlePacketReceived();
        }
    }

    private long timeout;
}

Then you can specify the timeout as

new IdlePacketHandler(10000); // number of milliseconds, this is 10 seconds [/quote]

Would that happen to be for Delta? And Would you put the “new IdlePacketHandler(10000);” under case 202?

Read full topic

Zymus it’s called when the server receives the packet from the client.
If I remember correctly, the packet is sent 1 time when the player is idle for 1 minute, and then sent every 10 seconds afterwards.

However, you can modify the client to just send it after 10 minutes.

You look in the client for something like:

super.idleTime++; if(super.idleTime > 4500) {
And change the 4500 to 45000.
[/quote]

Is it a packet sent from the client to the server? I thought it was one sent to the client?

Anyways, to get this effect without modifying the client, and requiring all of your players to download it again (if you don’t have an auto updater), you can do it on the server side.

In your Player class, you can add a field

public class Player {

Then you can specify the timeout as

taht’s what i would assume, ot the players could just decompile the client and remove the afk kicker.

EDIT:

left:i found the player.class file in my folder, but it’s not readable
middle: can’t find the class file in eclipse
right: folder showing the clas file

Anything i can do to read the file properly? what am i doing wrong?

Read full topic

Anyways, to get this effect without modifying the client, and requiring all of your players to download it again (if you don’t have an auto updater), you can do it on the server side.

item.title: Afk kicker
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“petterrs96, post:3, topic:548929”]the packet looks like this

[code]package org.hyperion.rs2.packet;

import org.hyperion.rs2.model.Player;
import org.hyperion.rs2.net.Packet;

public class IdlePacketHandler implements PacketHandler {

@Override
public void handle(Player player, Packet packet) {
	player.getActionSender().sendLogout(false);
}

}
[/code]

is there any way i can put a timer on it? like, say 10 minutes?[/quote]

You would have to modify it just a bit. What’s the logic for when to send the packet (ie. when is idlePacketHandler.handle() called)?

Read full topic
